title: NEURAL HEURISTICS FOR SAT SOLVING
abstract: We use neural graph networks with a message-passing architecture and an attention mechanism to enhance the branching heuristic in two SAT-solving algorithms. We report improvements of learned neural heuristics compared with two standard human-designed heuristics.
problem_description_natural: The paper addresses the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT), which involves determining whether there exists a satisfying assignment for a given propositional logic formula in conjunctive normal form (CNF). The authors focus on improving the branching heuristic—specifically the 'choose-literal' step—in complete backtracking-based SAT solvers like DPLL and CDCL. Instead of using traditional hand-crafted heuristics such as DLIS or JW-OS, they propose replacing this step with a learned policy from a neural network that predicts, for each literal, whether assigning it true leads to a satisfying solution. The goal is to reduce the number of branching decisions (i.e., search steps) required to solve SAT instances, particularly on larger problems with over 100 variables.
performance_metrics: percent of instances solved within 1000 steps
number of steps to find a solution

variables: $x_i$: binary decision variable for Boolean variable $v_i$, where $x_i=1$ if $v_i$ is true, $x_i=0$ if false

raw_latex_model: $$\begin{aligned} & \text{Minimize } 0 \\ & \text{Subject to } \sum_{i \in P_j} x_i + \sum_{i \in N_j} (1 - x_i) \geq 1, \quad \forall j=1,\ldots,m \\ & x_i \in \{0,1\}, \quad \forall i=1,\ldots,n \end{aligned}$$
algorithm_description: The paper uses neural graph networks with a message-passing architecture and an attention mechanism to enhance the branching heuristic in DPLL and CDCL SAT-solving algorithms, comparing performance with standard heuristics like DLIS and JW-OS.
